subject: Ouch
event:
Okay, I'm not even going to talk about today's Giants game or the one the Jets played on Thanksgiving.  The wounds are still weeping.  Sigh.

On other fronts, there's a couple of new interviews online for those few of you who are not yet tired of hearing me expound.  I talk about DREAMSONGS and genre and my middle initials with John J. Miller of THE NATIONAL REVIEW (not to be confused with John Jos. Miller, my sometimes collaborator and Wild Cards writer) at 

http://radio.nationalreview.com/betweenthecovers/post/?q=YTdlOWVlNGYxMmFkZjE1ZTc2ODY2NDZmNzcwYmQyYTg=

and answer questions for the readers of ENTERTAINMENT WEEKLY at

http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20161804,00.html

Oh, and I hope everyone reading this had a wonderful Thanksgiving.  Gobble, gobble.

comments.article: So, will this be another late season collapse by the Giants or will they pull it together? It doesn't look promising.
comments.subject: December Swoon

comments.article: My pessimism says late season collapse, *again*.
comments.subject: Re: December Swoon

comments.article:
Great interviews!

I do have one question for you, and I guess this would be as good a time as any...sorry I missed the EW submission :/

When writing a shorter piece of fiction (short story/novella/etc) how do you approach the world in which it takes place, and how is it different from a longer work (if it is)?

You have a great way of making a character's environment very tangible, yet for short fiction I can imagine that major world construction wouldn't be "economical" in terms of time.

And the Chiefs keep dropping like flies--games and personnel. Good thing I have college basketball to console me!

May your holiday season be warm and delightful.

Living in Kentucky, its pretty much the way of life around here. Football holds some modicum of interest for the early part of fall... now that the weather is getting cold, its time for the round ball!!!

Being a Chief's fan, I would assume you are a Jayhawk. Heckuva ballgame last night for them with Arizona.
comments.subject: B-Ball time

comments.article: I almost didn't watch the Vikings/Giants game because every time I watch the Giants destroy us it breaks my heart.  The 41-0 NFC Championship blowout... two years in a row where the Vikes started out awesome then got destroyed by the Giants sending us into a tailspin for the rest of the season.  Ahhhh, redemption against the Giants these past two meetings has been OH-SO-SWEET ;)  Although, I want you to be happy, so how about I hope the Giants still make the playoffs and we'll call it even?

When the Vikings and Giants square off, the better team usually loses--see 1996, 2003, 2004, 2005.  The exception would be 2000, when the better Giants team dominated the Purple in the NFC championship game.  But it was a joy to watch yesterday.  Keep the faith.
comments.subject: Go Purple

comments.upictitle: J.A.C.K. Inc.  Super Secret Ninja Force: chiburi
comments.article:
Thanks for the update and a Happy Thanksgiving to you as well.

Sorry, I was forced to root for the Cowboys. :(

Oh dear. There's a couple of different ironies in the fact that you're being interviewed at the National Review Online by John J. Miller. ;)

Good interview. As for football, at least your teams are better than the Dolphins. Maybe they'll be able to manage one, measly little win tonight... (who am I kidding?)

The Jets game wasn't as bad as I'd thought it'd be. They caught a couple interceptions and their offense made a few good plays. Their defense was terrible, however, and just looked smaller (in stature) than the Cowboys offense. In a way, I'm glad the Cowboys won. We need somebody to beat the Patriots at the Superbowl, and I'm picking the lesser of two evils.
comments.subject: NFL

comments.upictitle: Xray Is As Xray Does: canes
comments.article: It's a frightening day, indeed, when the Cowboys are the LESSER of two evils. ;-)
comments.subject: Re: NFL

comments.article:
The three most hated of football - Pats, Cowboys and Favre. Why? Why why why? We all hope for the future of our own teams -Lions- but they fall victim to the evil three time and time again. Can't wait til the 'Boys have double digit losses in 6+ seasons like some other teams I know...

Great interviews - I loved the wedding in SoS but it's when someone dies without any scene (two favs in Feast) that I grind my teeth. And I'm starting to look like an old toothless jimbo here.
comments.subject: Dark days of football

comments.article:
I'm stunned - my Vikes won, I would have never picked that. They barely squeak by against Oakland at home, trying their hardest to give them that game when the week before they were completely shut out and embarrassed by their biggest rival, the Pack. 1 (or 2?) weeks before they blow out a good Chargers team. You never know what Vikings team is going to show up it seems.

The Vikes have had Eli's number the last two games, that's uncanny the number of INT's the NFL's worst pass defense has against him.

I still think no amount of games like this makes up for that 41-0 debacle of an NFC championship game 3-4 years ago though.

I spent my Thanksgiving brewing beer. :)
comments.subject: wow

comments.article: Sounds like a good Turkey Day.  You are right about the championship game of the 200 season, but you can't live in yesteryear.  For a week, we can imagine that we actually have a team to cheer for.
comments.subject: Re: wow

comments.article:
I logged on to your website to check your T-Day commentary. I told myself, "I bet his title for it will be 'Ouch'." Guess I got it painfully right.

- N

P.S. I've been listening to your Dreamsongs audio book. Two thumbs up on that production. I really appreciated hearing you read your bio.
comments.subject: Am I psychic?

comments.article:
What's important is that the Cowboys won! *ducks behind her hardback copy of A Storm of Swords*

Sorry. I couldn't resist!

I read the second interview. Nice read. Aside, I entered Nanowrimo about a week and a half late, but since I'm leaving you a note, anyway... I just wanted to thank you for your work on (as you put it) "a sprawling novel". It is/was my single biggest inspiration to finally stop thinking, and start writing. Heh. All the same, I'm anxious for Dance.
I think it is becoming clear why the Jets and the Giants are losing....the gods are punishing George for not finishing DwD!  To get them back on the winning path George, your task is clear.
comments.subject: The Reason the NY Teams aren't winning

comments.article: I had posted a GRIN symbol but it was left off the original!
comments.subject: Re: The Reason the NY Teams aren't winning

comments.article:
Thanks for fielding the tough questions George. I am sorry you have to deal with fickle and impatient fans, but that comes with success I guess. I appreciate you giving updates here and your candor in dealing with your fans. Just so you know, I think you're doing it with class and decorum.
As far as losing readers because of the red wedding- That's freaking ridiculous!! That was a pivotal point that shaped (re-shaped) the political landscape of the 7 Kingdoms!! How can you stop reading there? That's where it gets interesting.
Even though my Bears beat the Donkeys yesterday, I think that their fate will be similar to the Jets: winning just enough to keep them out of the top draft spots, albeit with more disgrace considering they were last year's NFC Champs.
comments.subject: Great Interview!!

comments.article:
Agreed - I was stunned and hooked by Joffrey in the first book (trying to do this without spoliers) and knew that I found my favorite fantasy series of all time when the Red Wedding happened.

No one seems to have the balls to do that to any of their main characters and as tough as it is to read it adds so much to the suspense. And yeah, it's life. Valor Morghulis.

I hope that my favorite characters make it through the next books and sure, I'll be bummed out if they die but I'll never trade those Red Wedding moments and I hope GRRM has more in store.
comments.subject: Re: Great Interview!!

comments.article: The Patriots changed from demigods to mere mortals before my very eyes on Sunday night. The Eagles, with a third-string QB, took them right down to the wire. Might have had the game but for some poor play-calling in the last 4 minutes. Turns out the Pats secondary resembles Swiss Cheese for the short pass. So perhaps the Giants, or even the Jets, have a chance after all.
comments.subject: On the football bright side

comments.article: I'm with Ayla in the question session. Some homoerotic scenes between male characters would be nice.
Manning threw some great touchdown passes - a pity they were to the other team.

a. My college team lost to a DIAA team in the first game of the season and, contrary to popular opinion, SUCKED ALL SEASON. I don't want to hear how fabulous they were for beating ND, for example, when my son's Bantam A ice hockey team could have beaten that team.

b. My prof'l football team, the Detroit FREAKIN' Lions, have recently gone the distance to prove my main Detroit-sports-fandom maxim: "It is never too late in the season for a Detroit team to start to suck."

Color me cynical. I have tickets to the Frozen Four in April, in Denver. (I don't know if you like college sports or ice hockey, but...). Hopefully Michigan won't leave me rooting for MSU again this year....

Great interviews. I'm patient. I've got many other things on my to-read list. So, you know. I'll wait!!! In the meantime, GO LIONS. (I guess).
comments.subject: Football Fandom Folly

comments.article: What sort of spider is that eight legged cutie on your icon?
comments.subject: Re: Football Fandom Folly

comments.article:
Eli and the incredibly inconsistent Giants cost me $250 in a parlay on Sunday. I really hate them right now. Still, I think my beloved Packers will defeat the (loathsome, despicable, rancid, etc.) Cowboys on Thursday. The Packers are for real and Favre, as I have been saying for the past 3 years, still has what it takes to win.

Dallas, on the other hand, has beat ONE team with a winning record: the Giants.
comments.subject: The Giants and Cowboys and Packers

comments.article: Dance With Dragons, Schmance With Dragons.  I'd way rather read about football and trading cards.
comments.subject: yayy

comments.upictitle: ne m'incitez pas  descendre l: Caitlyn
comments.article:
Dance with Dragons - so much better than any football game.
Really.
Truely.
Need the book.
It's like crack.
Must have my fix.
SOON.

Just a subtle hint.
Pretty please?

(And don't kill a Stark just cause I asked about the book, please?)
Since anyone can die... how much in pledges would it take to kill off Daenerys?
She's probably too much fun to write. :)

The Titans have been in a bit of slide for three weeks now.
On a positive note I realized looking at the GRRM Bibliograhy that the seven book Ice and Fire series is doing very well time-wise especially considering the size of each book. I'm guessing Dragons comes out in 2008. That's five big honking and very well-written books in just twelve years. (See below.)
Congratulations, GRRM, you're doing great. Good work. And thanks for your efforts.
A Song of Ice and Fire:
o A Game of Thrones, Bantam Books, 1996
o A Clash of Kings, Bantam Books, 1999
o A Storm of Swords, Bantam Books, 2000
o A Feast for Crows, Bantam Books, 2005
o A Dance with Dragons, forthcoming/Bantam Books
o The Winds of Winter, forthcoming/Bantam Books
o A Dream of Spring, forthcoming/Bantam Books
comments.subject: I feel your pain.

comments.article: I don't know why you would think that DANCE will come out in 2008.
comments.subject: Re: I feel your pain.

comments.article: I was very surprised at the Vikings - Giants game. I thought for sure the Giants were going to annihilate the Vikings as the Vikings have had a very off year. I'm from Minnesota but I'm not a Vikings fan. However, I don't mind the Giants.
comments.subject: Football

comments.article:
Good interview - I'm glad you post your interviews at LJ otherwise I might never find them.
Before I read your answer to the death question I immediately thought of Ned Stark. Not b/c I thought you got the most flak for his death but b/c his sticks out the most in my mind. Before Game of Thrones the last time I had encountered the death of a character that I loved was when I was 10 reading Bridge to Tarabithia. After Ned's death I felt I had changed as a reader. And honestly I like the suspense. It makes the story feel that much more real. Sure the Red Wedding was hard to read but it didnt have quite the same effect on me as that first gut wrenching death of the "good guy" did. So thanks for keeping us on our toes even if it does piss us off when we lose beloved characters!
comments.subject: interview
